channel.title: The Chuck ToddCast: Meet the Press
channel.description: Chuck Todd at his best – unscripted, informed and focused on what really matters in politics. Join Chuck each Wednesday as he talks with top reporters from the nation’s capital, plus exclusive sit-down interviews and on-the-ground dispatches from across the campaign trail.

image.title: The Chuck ToddCast: Meet the Press

channel.itunes:summary: Chuck Todd at his best – unscripted, informed and focused on what really matters in politics. Join Chuck each Wednesday as he talks with top reporters from the nation’s capital, plus exclusive sit-down interviews and on-the-ground dispatches from across the campaign trail.

item.title: Post Game: Biden’s credibility
item.description: After the messy Afghanistan withdrawal, mixed-messaging on Covid booster shots and a rising migration problem at the southern border, Chuck talks with Executive Producer John Reiss about what made it on-air and what we learned on Sunday.
item.author: nbcnews.podcasts@gmail.com (NBC News)
item.content:encoded: After the messy Afghanistan withdrawal, mixed-messaging on Covid booster shots and a rising migration problem at the southern border, Chuck talks with Executive Producer John Reiss about what made it on-air and what we learned on Sunday.
item.itunes:title: Post Game: Biden’s credibility
item.itunes:author: NBC News
item.itunes:summary: Executive Producer John Reiss joins Chuck to unpack interviews with Dr. Fauci and Sen. Bill Cassidy (R-La.).
item.itunes:subtitle: Executive Producer John Reiss joins Chuck to unpack interviews with Dr. Fauci and Sen. Bill Cassidy (R-La.).

item.title: George Will: Where conservatives go now
item.description: Chuck talks with George Will, syndicated columnist and the author of a new book, “American Happiness and Discontents,” in which he writes about Afghanistan, social-distancing and of course, American history.
item.author: nbcnews.podcasts@gmail.com (NBC News)
item.content:encoded: Chuck talks with George Will, syndicated columnist and the author of a new book, “American Happiness and Discontents,” in which he writes about Afghanistan, social-distancing and of course, American history.

item.itunes:subtitle: George Will talks to Chuck Todd about the true meaning of conservatism in an age of Trumpism.

item.title: What Newsom's win means for the midterms
item.description: California Governor Gavin Newsom easily beat back a recall effort this week, thanks to trends inside the state’s Democratic electorate … and thanks to the ongoing shifts inside the Republican party in the wake of former President Trump. Chuck talks with Christina Bellantoni, Director of the Annenberg Media Center at the University of Southern California and Tim Miller, political strategist and writer at the Bulwark.
item.author: nbcnews.podcasts@gmail.com (NBC News)

item.title: ‘There’s no quick fix to this’: Sen. Ben Nelson talks about repairing the Senate
item.description: Ben Nelson, former Democratic senator from Nebraska, built a reputation from 2000 to 2013 pushing for bipartisanship and bucking his party. He joins Chuck to talk about his new book, “Death of the Senate.”
item.author: nbcnews.podcasts@gmail.com (NBC News)
item.content:encoded: Ben Nelson, former Democratic senator from Nebraska, built a reputation from 2000 to 2013 pushing for bipartisanship and bucking his party. He joins Chuck to talk about his new book, “Death of the Senate.”

item.title: Abortion and the 2022 midterms: Cornell Belcher & Kristen Soltis Anderson
item.description: With a little more than a year to go before the midterms, the terms of the campaign are still in flux. Kristen Soltis Anderson, Republican pollster and co-founder of Echelon Insights joins Cornell Belcher, Democratic pollster and president of Brilliant Corners Research and Strategies, talk to Chuck about the political impact of the Texas abortion law.
item.author: nbcnews.podcasts@gmail.com (NBC News)
item.content:encoded: With a little more than a year to go before the midterms, the terms of the campaign are still in flux. Kristen Soltis Anderson, Republican pollster and co-founder of Echelon Insights joins Cornell Belcher, Democratic pollster and president of Brilliant Corners Research and Strategies, talk to Chuck about the political impact of the Texas abortion law.

item.title: Mark Sanford: The fight against polarization
item.description: If you take a close look at almost every political issue today — whether it’s Covid, voting, policing or climate — you will find one problem at the root of it: Polarization. Mark Sanford, former South Carolina governor (R) and former congressman talks to Chuck about partisanship in politics and his new book, “Two Roads Diverged.”
item.author: nbcnews.podcasts@gmail.com (NBC News)
item.content:encoded: If you take a close look at almost every political issue today — whether it’s Covid, voting, policing or climate — you will find one problem at the root of it: Polarization. item.title: Richard Engel: 'Consequences' in Afghanistan will be felt across the world
item.description: President Biden spoke from the White House to defend his decision to pull forces out of the country, but his legacy may be more about the “how” than the “why” ... And that’s assuming that Afghanistan doesn’t once again become a haven for terrorist attacks. NBC News Chief Foreign Correspondent Richard Engel talks about his firsthand reporting from Kabul as the U.S. mission came to an end.
item.author: nbcnews.podcasts@gmail.com (NBC News)

item.title: Would cloned college could solve higher education’s problems?
item.description: For years, top universities have been overwhelmed by potentially qualified student candidates, but unable to fit them on campus … leading to a race to the top that no student can ever really win, often leaving students from diverse backgrounds struggling for a chance to get ahead. Professor David Kirp proposes a radical idea to expand the world of higher education.
item.author: nbcnews.podcasts@gmail.com (NBC News)
item.content:encoded: For years, top universities have been overwhelmed by potentially qualified student candidates, but unable to fit them on campus … leading to a race to the top that no student can ever really win, often leaving students from diverse backgrounds struggling for a chance to get ahead. Professor David Kirp proposes a radical idea to expand the world of higher education.
item.itunes:title: Would cloned college could solve higher education’s problems?
item.itunes:author: NBC News
item.itunes:summary: David Kirp Professor at the University of California, Berkeley, joins Chuck to talk about a radical idea that could change college.

item.title: That's how the sausage get's made: Senate moves ahead
item.description: On Tuesday, the Senate passed a bipartisan infrastructure bill and sent it to the House. Then they immediately celebrated by starting the process of passing a 3.5 trillion dollar spending package with a record-breaking vote-a-rama that wrapped up a little before 4 AM.
item.author: nbcnews.podcasts@gmail.com (NBC News)
item.content:encoded: On Tuesday, the Senate passed a bipartisan infrastructure bill and sent it to the House. Then they immediately celebrated by starting the process of passing a 3.5 trillion dollar spending package with a record-breaking vote-a-rama that wrapped up a little before 4 AM.

item.title: In post-Covid poll, Americans say they are "thriving"
item.description:
As troops leave Afghanistan, Sen. Jack Reed (D-R.I.) talks about what the end to America’s longest war may mean for our influence on the world stage. Rep. Adam Kinzinger (R-Ill.) discusses the influence of far-right extremism in the GOP.

Carrie Dann’s final number of the week looks at Americans’ optimistic feelings about the future.
item.author: nbcnews.podcasts@gmail.com (NBC News)
item.content:encoded:
As troops leave Afghanistan, Sen. Jack Reed (D-R.I.) talks about what the end to America’s longest war may mean for our influence on the world stage. Rep. Adam Kinzinger (R-Ill.) discusses the influence of far-right extremism in the GOP.

Carrie Dann’s final number of the week looks at Americans’ optimistic feelings about the future.
item.itunes:title: In post-Covid poll, Americans say they are "thriving"
item.itunes:author: NBC News
item.itunes:summary: Plus, Chuck recaps his interviews with Sen. Jack Reed (D-R.I.) and Rep. Adam Kinzinger (R-Ill.) as American forces withdraw from Afghanistan.
item.itunes:subtitle: Plus, Chuck recaps his interviews with Sen. Jack Reed (D-R.I.) and Rep. Adam Kinzinger (R-Ill.) as American forces withdraw from Afghanistan.

item.title: Just how broken is campaign finance law enforcement with Shane Goldmacher
item.description: The FEC is responsible for enforcing federal finance laws and it’s led by an equal number of Republicans and Democrats — in theory that should create a spirit of cooperation. But in today’s environment, that divide creates more “deadlock” than “bipartisan enforcement.” Shane Goldmacher, national political reporter for the New York Times, joins Chuck to talk about the failures at the FEC and what it means for campaign finance law.
item.author: nbcnews.podcasts@gmail.com (NBC News)
item.content:encoded: The FEC is responsible for enforcing federal finance laws and it’s led by an equal number of Republicans and Democrats — in theory that should create a spirit of cooperation. But in today’s environment, that divide creates more “deadlock” than “bipartisan enforcement.” Shane Goldmacher, national political reporter for the New York Times, joins Chuck to talk about the failures at the FEC and what it means for campaign finance law.

item.title: The summer of infrastructure with Benjy Sarlin & Tara Palmeri
item.description: Washington is emptying out ahead of the July fourth weekend … with the Senate in recess and the House leaving town for two weeks on Thursday afternoon. Before they go, Congressional Democrats will vote to create a select committee on January 6th. Still on the table — how will Washington move forward on infrastructure.

item.title: Power serves: Democrats in New Mexico and the evolution of athletic activism
item.description:
New Mexico's special election signals an environment that favors Democrats ahead of 2022, while Biden fights a cybersecurity war ahead of his summit with Putin. NBC's Shannon Pettypiece and Ben Kamisar join. 

 

Later, Washington Post Sports Columnist Jerry Brewer weighs in on Naomi Osaka and the sometimes "toxic environment" between sports players and the press.

item.title: Trump grand jury: Huge … but significant? Plus, John Glenn’s legacy
item.description:
Jacqueline Alemany, author of the Washington Post’s early morning newsletter, PowerUp and Edward-Isaac Dovere, staff writer at the Atlantic and author of the new book, “Battle for the Soul: Inside the Democrats’ campaign to defeat Trump,” join Chuck to talk about a New York grand jury that’s looking into the Trump organization.

Jeff Shesol, author of “Mercury Rising: John Glenn, John Kennedy, and the New Battleground of the Cold War,” talks about one presidential campaign that never got off the launchpad.

item.title: Republicans feud over Trump, Cheney and immigration; Plus Facebook upholds Trump ban
item.description:
The internal feud between House Republicans broke out into the open once again this week, as Liz Cheney, the number three Republican, faces calls for her ouster from leadership because she continues to disagree with former President Trump. Chuck is joined by deputy editorial page editor for the Washington Post, Ruth Marcus and Lachlan Markay, politics reporter at Axios.

Plus, former GOP congressman Reid Ribble discusses the GOP’s changes on immigration.

item.title: Digital espionage, cyber war and a the end of American troops in Afghanistan: Nicole Perlroth & Rep. Barbara Lee
item.description:
Nicole Perlroth, New York Times reporter covering digital espionage and author of “This Is How They Tell Me The World Ends,” joins Chuck to uncover what's really happening with America's cyberwar.

 

Twenty years after her lone vote to oppose a broad use of force authorization following September 11th, and on the same day that President Biden announced his plan to withdraw from Afghanistan, Rep. Barbara Lee (D-Calif.) talks to Chuck about America's longest war.
item.author: nbcnews.podcasts@gmail.com (NBC News)

item.title: Domestic Extremism: ‘They aren’t wearing hoods, but slacks’
item.description: The dotted line from before the Oklahoma City bombing to the anti-mask protests and the Gretchen Whitmer kidnapping plot to the Jan. 6th Capitol attack. Why does America have an  apparent inclination toward violent extremism? How are populism,  grievance politics and nationalism  playing into that inclination across the political spectrum? And what can law enforcement, national  security experts and elected officials do to turn  down the temperature? Or, is it too late?
item.author: nbcnews.podcasts@gmail.com (NBC News)
item.content:encoded: The dotted line from before the Oklahoma City bombing to the anti-mask protests and the Gretchen Whitmer kidnapping plot to the Jan. 6th Capitol attack. Why does America have an  apparent inclination toward violent extremism? How are populism,  grievance politics and nationalism  playing into that inclination across the political spectrum? And what can law enforcement, national  security experts and elected officials do to turn  down the temperature? Or, is it too late?
item.itunes:title: Domestic Extremism: ‘They aren’t wearing hoods, but slacks’
item.itunes:author: NBC News
item.itunes:summary: How violent domestic extremism has infected our politics, and how the Jan. 6th attack was only one instance in its long history and potentially violent future.
item.itunes:subtitle: How violent domestic extremism has infected our politics, and how the Jan. 6th attack was only one instance in its long history and potentially violent future.

item.title: The Biden agenda: Eli Stokols & Shannon Pettypiece, Plus Mike Isaac and Elizabeth Dwokin
item.description:
Shannon Pettypiece Senior White House Reporter for NBC News Digital and Eli Stokols White House reporter for the LA Times join Chuck to talk about how Republicans are reckoning with Biden's Washington.

 

Plus, Facebook and Australia have come to an agreement to allow news links to be shared on the social media platform after Australia tried to give news organizations more leverage. Mike Isaac, technology correspondent at the New York Times, and Elizabeth Dwoskin, Silicon Valley Correspondent of the Washington Post, explain.

Plus, Kiersten Todt, managing director at the Cyber Readiness Institute, discusses a hack that could have poisoned municipal water in Florida.

 

To read Bruce's presentation:

item.title: Something's wrong with Washington
item.description: In a week where the president cancelled a trip to Denmark because of a spat over Greenland, considered letting Russia off the hook for invading Crimea and sided with Israel in a fight with two American congresswomen, Chuck Todd asks what is wrong with Washington. This week's guests, author and columnist Matt Bai, Politico White House reporter Gabby Orr. Plus an interview with the Wall Street Journal's Chief Economics reporter, Nick Timiraos.

item.title: Mueller speaks! And Chuck talks with Adm. McRaven
item.description: In a surprise public statement, Robert Mueller outlines the principal conclusions of the Special Counsel investigation. NBC News correspondent Carol Lee and Washington Post Senior Congressional Correspondent Paul Kane talk about the next steps for Congress. Plus, Chuck is joined by Retired Admiral WIlliam McRaven to talk about his career leading the Navy SEALS and his role in the raid to kill Osama bin Laden.

The mid-week, in-the-know podcast is Chuck at his best – unscripted, informed and focused on what really matters in the 2020 presidential race. Join Chuck each Wednesday as he talks with by top reporters from the nation’s capital, plus exclusive sit-down interviews and on-the-ground dispatches from across the campaign trail.

item.title: Maureen Orth: Versace's killer might have found other outlets today
item.description: Maureen Orth’s 1999 book, Vulgar Favors: Andrew Cunanan, Gianni Versace, and the Largest Failed Manhunt in U.S. History, is now the backdrop of FX’s nine-part series, “The Assassination of Gianni Versace: American Crime Story”. But while the TV show may shine the spotlight on Versace, Orth’s book dug deeper into the complex mind of Cunanan -- why he killed, how he hid in plain sight and why he targeted Versace.
item.author: nbcnews.podcasts@gmail.com (NBC News)

Mike McFaul, Former Amb. Wendy Sherman & Jeremy Bash, this audio recording has been lightly edited for clarity and pacing.

item.title: Chemically Polluted Water in West Virginia Becomes Flashpoint
item.description: When director Cullen Hoback began work on his latest documentary, "What Lies Upstream," he hoped to find out why it took months for local officials in West Virginia to investigate chemically contaminated tap water.   But his initial investigation into chemically polluted drinking water in West Virginia soon expanded into a far-reaching analysis of local regulators’ inability, and in some cases unwillingness, to safeguard the people and resources they were entrusted to protect.

item.title: Putin's Blindspots: Inside Russia with Susan Glasser
item.description: Susan Glasser, former editor of Politico, joins Chuck to talk about how relations with Russia got to where they are, what Putin hopes to get from the United States, and whether Russia is primed for a revolution. Glasser also discusses Buzzfeed's decision to release an unverified memo about the President-elect.

item.title: Before Obama's Farewell, Looking Back at his Speeches with E.J. Dionne & Joy-Ann Reid
item.description: Joy-Ann Reid and E.J. Dionne, co-editors of "We Are the Change We Seek: The Speeches of Barack Obama" sat down with Chuck Todd to talk about the impact of Barack Obama's speeches. With a week to go before Obama's farewell address, they look back on Obama's speeches on race, his eulogies, and what to expect from Donald Trump's speeches.

item.title: Astronaut Kate Rubins: Voting From Space
item.description: Kate Rubins is an astronaut and biologist on board the International Space Station. During her time on the ISS, Rubins became the first person to sequence DNA microgravity - but she's also had to help maintain the space station, and even repair the toilet plumbing. She talks with Chuck about how NASA helps her cast her ballot if she doesn't make it back to Earth before the election.
